REVISED RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN FOR
OTAY MESA ENERGY CENTER
Prepared for:
Calpine Corporation
Otay Mesa Energy Center
San Diego, California
September 2018

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
This document represents the revised Risk Management Plan (RMP) for the facility operated by Calpine Corporation under the name of Otay Mesa Energy Center, LLC (OMEC) located in San Diego County, California. This document has been revised and updated in order to address the following issues:
¿	Accomplish the required 5 year RMP revision process, and,
¿	Address the Program status change from Level 2 to Level 1.
The RMP addresses the requirements of the California Accidental Release Program (CalARP) as adopted by the State of California as outlined in California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 19. These requirements build upon the provisions of the "general duty clause" of the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990, and the federal RMP program requirements in 40 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 68, which require the following activities of all facilities which produce, process, store, or handle listed substances:
¿	identify hazards
¿	design and maintain a safe facility
¿	prevent releases
¿	minimize consequences of releases
The accepted approach to accomplishing the above is to have a documented RMP, which outlines all the steps and procedures a facility will take to prevent and mitigate accidental releases. OMEC has chosen to revise and implement this RMP in support of continued operations of the aqueous ammonia process systems in order to fulfill its obligations with respect to the General Duty clause and to protect its employees and the surrounding community from the effects of accidental releases.
Pursuant to 40 CFR 68 and the CalARP regulations, the following summary is given:
The RMP applies to the OMEC facility located at:
606 De La Fuente Court, San Diego, CA 92154
The OMEC facility is a natural gas fired combined cycle (2X1) nominal rated 596 megawatt (MW) powerplant. The fac

ility consists of two combustion turbines and common to both turbines is a steam turbine generator. The facility has a "selective catalytic reduction (SCR)" system, on each of the turbines, for the control of oxides of nitrogen (NOx) emissions. Aqueous ammonia (29.4 percent solution) is used as the reaction reagent in the presence of a precious metal catalyst to complete the NOx emissions control process. Aqueous ammonia is stored in a stationary storage tank rated at 16,000 gallons, filled to 85 percent capacity. Aqueous ammonia will be delivered to the site approximately every 6 days.
Substance Used/Stored:  Aqueous Ammonia 29.4 Percent Solution (CAS# 7664-41-7)
Facility SIC: 4911	NAICS Code: 221112
In addition to the above ammonia storage system, the facility also uses small quantity totes of aqueous ammonia in various other processes. These totes store less than 400 gallons each of aqueous ammonia solution (19%).
The facility would not be subject to the Process Safety Management provisions of 29 CFR 1910 and California Code of Regulations (CCR) Title 8 Section 5189. In addition, facility staff as well as Calpine corporate staff believe the facility meets all the requirements for a Program Level 1 facility. Based on the above, the facility is being re-classified to a Program Level 1 source.
The OMEC facility has not experienced an accidental release of ammonia or any other hazardous substance in the last 5 years.
Training
A program Level 1 RMP does not require a training element.

A program Level 1 RMP does not require a maintenance element.

1.0	  FACILITY AND PROCESS DESCRIPTIONS
Otay Mesa Energy Center, LLC is a 596 megawatt (MW) (nominal) power plant facility near city of San Diego, CA. This plant is located at 606 De La Fuente Court, San Diego, California 92154. The facility utilizes combined-cycle combustion turbine technology in the electrical generation process. The project consists of (2) natural gas fired turbines and associated duct burners, a single steam turbine, and associated support equipment. 
The Otay Mesa Energy Center LLC is comparable to the majority of Calpine's energy centers; the OMEC is a combined-cycle design that enables it to generate electricity up to 40 percent more efficiently than traditional natural gas-fueled facilities. The project also incorporates best available emissions control technology. The turbines are equipped with dry low nitrogen (NOx) combustors and "selective catalytic reduction" (SCR) for the control of emissions of oxides of NOx. The SCR system uses aqueous ammonia as the reduction reagent. As such, the facility has the required systems to store and distribute aqueous ammonia for the SCR process.
The facility is storing aqueous ammonia on site in a stationary non-pressurized storage tank with a capacity of approximately 16,000 gallons. Aqueous ammonia solution of 29.4 percent (or less) by weight ammonia is being used. Administrative controls limit the actual tank storage capacity to 85 percent of maximum design capacity, i.e., 13,600 gallons. The tank is situated within a secondary containment area of sufficient size and volume to contain the entire contents of the tank plus the rainfall from the worst-case storm scenario. The ammonia storage and handling facilities is equipped with continuous tank level monitors, temperature and pressure monitors and alarms. In additio

n to the main SCR system ammonia storage, the facility also uses aqueous ammonia in small totes. These totes have a capacity of less than 400 gallons each and store aqueous ammonia in solutions less than 20% ammonia by weight.
1.1	RMP PROGRAM LEVEL
Storage of 13,600 gallons of aqueous ammonia results in the on-site presence of ammonia in quantities in excess of the State CalARP substance threshold for ammonia of 500 pounds. Presently, the CalARP regulations do not contain an exemption for aqueous ammonia solutions. The federal RMP regulations per 40 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 68 contain an exemption for aqueous ammonia solutions less than 20 percent with a threshold value of 10,000 pounds. Since the facility is proposing the use of 29.4 percent aqueous ammonia, these exemptions would not apply to the current facility, and as such, the facility must prepare and maintain a RMP for aqueous ammonia. The existing facility is not subject to the Process Safety Management provisions of 29 CFR 1910 and California Code of Regulations (CCR) Title 8 Section 5189. Based on the above, including the accident history, and a lack of potential offsite impact receptors, the existing facility is being re-classified as a Program Level 1 source. 
1.1.1	RMP Management System
The OMEC facility has included in its current management system the required elements to oversee the implementation of the RMP program elements. The plant manager has been selected to be the RMP Manager and will be delegated the overall responsibility for implementation and integration of the RMP elements. 
The management system currently in-place at the facility satisfies the requirements of the CalARP and U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) RMP regulations and ensures that the RMP elements will be developed and continually improved. All records associated with the RMP will be retained for a minimum of five years unless another period is specifically delineated within the applicable state or federa

l RMP regulations.
1.1.2	RMP Team Responsibilities
The RMP Manager and Team commit to the implementation of the following RMP management goals and tasks: 
¿	Annual review and update of the facility operating procedures.
¿	Update the RMP per CCR 19, Section 2745.10(b), as follows:
-	Within 5 years of its initial submission or most recent update required by Sections (b)(2) through (b)(7)
-	No later than 3 years after a newly regulated substance is first listed by OES
-	No later than the date on which a new regulated substance is first present in an already covered process above a threshold quantity
-	No later than the date on which a regulated substance is first present above a threshold quantity in a new process
-	Within 6 months of a change that requires a revised process hazards analysis (PHA) or hazard review
-	Within 6 months of a change that requires a revised offsite consequence analysis per 2750.7
-	Within 6 months of a change that alters the Program level that applied to any covered process
This document has been prepared to satisfy the Program Level 1 requirements of the CalARP regulations as delineated in CCR, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, and Title 40 CFR Part 68 respectively, as administered by the San Diego County Certified Unified Program Agency (CUPA).
Calpine and OMEC staff believe that the procedures and practices delineated herein are sufficient to minimize the potential for chemical accidents when properly implemented and followed.
 
2.0	  FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
The proposed power plant is an existing operating facility. 
The facility has had no accidental releases of ammonia in the last 5 years.
The purpose of the 5-year accident history is to present data to the local emergency planning committee and the public pertaining to past accidental releases at the target facility. The data is used as follows:
¿	Provides an explanation to the public regarding the factors, which caused or contributed to a release.
¿	Provides da

ta on the offsite consequences of such releases.
¿	Provides data on what steps were taken by the target facility to investigate and minimize future releases.
¿	Helps to create an informed public.

16.0		OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS
The offsite consequence analysis was conducted using the SLAB model. SLAB is a computer based dispersion model, developed by the Lawrence Livermore Laboratory, which simulates the atmospheric dispersion of denser-than-air as well as neutrally buoyant releases. Atmospheric dispersion of the release is calculated by solving the conservation equations of mass, momentum, energy, and species. The mathematical description of the physics of heavy gas dispersion, as well as the description of the normal atmospheric advection and turbulent diffusions processes, are inherently included in the conservation equations within SLAB. Table 16-1 delineates the data used in the modeling runs and release scenarios, as derived from the HR and emissions analysis.

Explanation of table values:

With respect to the release rates given in Table 16-1, note the following:
¿	Aqueous ammonia is a water based ammonia solution, which can be mixed and delivered, in a wide variety of solution ratios. Solution mix ratios less than 30 percent (weight basis) are the most common. When spilled, aqueous ammonia solutions will slowly vaporize, releasing ammonia vapors. According to data prepared for the California Energy Commission (CEC) by Ebasco (Ammonia Release Risk Mitigation Guidance for Power Plants-Draft Report, November 1989) when ammonia is diluted with water to solutions of less than or equal to 20 percent by volume, evaporation of ammonia gas from the fluid becomes negligible. The guidance further states that when ammonia is diluted with water at ambient temperatures to solutions less than 25 percent by weight, ammonia vapor pressure is re

duced to atmospheric pressure, i.e., the evaporation of ammonia gas from the aqueous fluid would be negligible as opposed to a release of anhydrous ammonia which would be rapid and much more severe with respect to offsite impacts.
¿	Per Risk Management Program Guidance for WWTPs, EPA-OSWER, October 1998, ammonia emissions from aqueous ammonia releases are only calculated for the first 10 minutes of the spill life. EPA states that the release of ammonia from the aqueous solution should only be used for the first 10 minutes after which the ammonia in the pool or diked area will be more dilute than it was initially and will be evaporating much less rapidly. This qualifier applies to all emissions scenarios except to the alternate case for which a conservative assumption was made that all ammonia contained in the spilled product would be released within 10 minutes.
16.1	EMISSIONS CALCULATION PROCEDURES
Emissions of ammonia from the aqueous solution were calculated for the worst case scenario using the following equation:
QR = (1.4)(LFA)(A)(Tcf)
Where: LFA, for 29-30% aqueous ammonia ambient liquid factor (0.026), or for 19% aqueous ammonia (0.015):
A, is the surface area of the spill or release, sq.ft.,
QR, is the emission in units of lbs/min.
Tcf, temperature correction factor (not used as the San Diego CUPA specified 25 C for all worst case OCA analyses)
The LFA factors are based on data presented in RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance, April 15, 1999, Table B-3 and Appendix D.2.2 respectively.
The surface area for non-diked spills is based on a spill depth of 1 cm. The spill surface area can be calculated as follows:
Sfc.Area (m2) = (total gallons spilled)/(2.642)
(m2) X (10.76) = sq.ft.
For purposes of maintaining a conservative emission release for the alternate scenario, all ammonia contained within the total spill for non-diked (ground surface) releases was assumed emitted over the 10-minute time frame. It should be noted that the unloading are

a is partially diked as well, but the amount of the proposed release covers an area smaller than the diked surface area, therefore, the spill area is based on the spill amount as noted above.
